importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: Landmark study (LEAP) published in 2015 changed recommendations on peanut introduction, showing early exposure reduces allergy risk.
National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases updated guidelines in 2017 to recommend early peanut introduction for high-risk infants.
The LEAP study found a significant drop in peanut allergy prevalence after guideline changes, marking a turning point in allergy prevention.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The 10-year period from 2015 to 2025 shows the long-term impact of revised pediatric allergy guidelines on food allergy rates in the U.S.

keyTakeAways: Early introduction of peanuts (around 4–6 months of age) significantly reduces the risk of developing a peanut allergy.
A 43% reduction in peanut allergy prevalence and a 36% reduction in overall food allergy prevalence were observed in U.S. children after guideline changes.
The change in recommendations, based on the 2015 LEAP study, has prevented at least 40,000 cases of peanut allergy and around 60,000 cases of food allergy over the past decade.
The shift in guidance helped move peanuts from being the leading cause of food allergy in U.S. children under 3.
The study used data from over 120,000 U.S. children across multiple pediatric practices to assess the impact of early allergen introduction.
Limitations include reliance on diagnostic codes (not actual consumption) and lack of detailed data on children’s eating habits.
Experts like Dr. Corinne Keet remain cautious due to potential under-implementation of guidelines and diagnostic bias.
Only about 10% of children with peanut allergies outgrow them, indicating long-term health impacts.

namedEntities.name: Dr. David Hill
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Pediatric allergist and lead researcher of the study
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: He led the study that analyzed allergy trends post-2015 guidelines, providing key findings on reduced allergy rates due to early peanut exposure.

namedEntities.name: Dr. Corinne Keet
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Pediatrics professor and expert on food allergy epidemiology
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: She offers cautionary perspective on the study’s results, noting potential under-implementation of guidelines and limitations in data interpretation.

namedEntities.name: LEAP Study

namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: It provided the scientific basis for reversing peanut allergy prevention advice and launched the shift in pediatric health guidelines.

summaryOfNewsArticle: A new study published in the journal Pediatrics shows that reversing the long-standing advice to avoid peanuts in infants has significantly reduced food allergies in the U.S. The shift, spurred by a landmark 2015 study (LEAP) that found early peanut exposure reduces allergy risk, led to updated guidelines from the National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases and the Dietary Guidelines for Americans. Researchers analyzed health data from over 120,000 children and found a 43% drop in peanut allergy prevalence and a 36% drop in overall food allergy rates over the past decade, preventing at least 40,000 cases of peanut allergy. While experts like Dr. Corinne Keet caution about data limitations and incomplete guideline implementation, the results confirm a major public health benefit: peanut allergies, which are often lifelong, have been effectively reduced through early allergen introduction.

title: Reversing peanut advice prevented tens of thousands of allergy cases, researchers say
